Award.AwardTitle: A Wirelessly Preemptive Sensing System for Quasi-Realtime Earthquake Monitoring of Bridges

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration: Measuring the earthquake response of a bridge is an important function for low power wireless sensor networks (WSNs). Past experience with the current generation of WSNs demonstrated that earthquakes have hit an instrumented bridge and the network completely missed it because it was either in energy-saving sleep mode or transferring ambient data that was collected prior to the earthquake. The research objectives of this project are to test the hypothesis that a wireless sensor network capable of being preemptively triggered can capture the critical dynamic response of a bridge during and after an earthquake, and that it can conduct distributed modal identification so that the agility of damage characterization and the efficiency of energy consumption of the bridge monitoring system can be improved. The impact of the project will be in advancing discovery, multi-disciplinary collaboration, teaching, and training. The proposed research will enable bridge monitoring not previously possible by conventional methods, which contributes to protecting society through transformative improvements in methods for timely detection of bridge response to earthquakes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of this project were to create a near realtime sensing system to respond to an incoming earthquake, collect critical strong motion data, intelligently decide the portion of the data that can be processed on-board and transmit the summary necessary for modal processing, and create a framework for identifying structural damage. These goals were achieved by creating new knowledge and developing technology to address each issue separately but with consideration of the limitations and constraints of the other issues.

More specifically, the distributed and stochastic data processing methods are best suitable for low power wireless sensor networks, in which the cost of data transmission is very high at the same time that significant on-board computational capabilities exist. This makes the distributed and in-network solutions to data processing more critical by allowing them to manage limited power resources in a wireless system.  Two such algorithms are proposed and verified through this project. One utilizes the sparsity of the correlation matrix and imposes restriction on it so each sensor node effectively considers its close neighbors in reporting its data. The other creates a parametric model of the structure and hands it over from sensor node to sensor node, so each node can modify it consistent with its measured data.  

To date, the data measured by a low power wireless sensor system generally consists of vibrations, strain, and environmental parameters. This is a fact driven by the market: accelerometers are cheap, reliable, and easy to work thanks to the advanced in micro electro mechanical systems technology. Strain gauges are the most widely used sensors in structural engineering research and diagnostics. An inexpensive wireless unit is justified only if the entire system is easy to handle and overall inexpensive. This paradigm may change in the future with the advent of more sophisticated and equally accessible sensing systems, but that change is unlike to occur anytime soon. As a result, a focus of this project was to utilize the measured data from the existing systems and produce information that help detect the existence and location of structural damage. To this end, a damage detection platform was created which consists of several damage-sensitive features (based on regression models in both time and space), a comprehensive threshold construction mechanism and probabilistic change point detection methodology to quantify the confidence in identifying structural damage.

The hardware and software components developed by this project are also inspired by the intended application. The hardware platform called sandwich node is a novel concept to provide dedicated processing units for measurement, time-synchronization, and communication. By doing so, a wireless system can preserve its limited power resources but at the same time demonstrate a higher level of performance in response to earthquake motions. Based on the hardware capability, we have designed a pipelining algorithm for data collection in a multiple-hop wireless sensor network that enables an optimal data collection schedule to minimize the communication delay performance for the quasi-realtime earthquake monitoring of bridges.

The methods and findings of this project are integrated in new and existing courses that benefit both undergraduate and graduate students. A multi-disciplinary course was introduced and offered by the PI which has become a part of Civil Engineering curriculum. The concept of wireless sensing for earthquake monitoring of bridges was introduced by the Co-PI in Wireless Sensing Labs for freshmen students in engineering.
